title: Ohm's Law Calculation
description: Calculate the current flowing through a resistor when a voltage is applied across it.
solution: Using Ohm's Law, I = V/R. For example, if V = 10V and R = 5Ω, then I = 2A.

title: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law
description: Given a closed circuit loop with multiple voltage sources, determine the missing voltage.
solution: Apply Kirchhoff's Voltage Law: the sum of the voltage gains equals the sum of the voltage drops in a closed loop.

title: Resistor Network Equivalent
description: Determine the equivalent resistance of a combination of resistors in series and parallel.
solution: For resistors in series, add them directly. For parallel, use 1/Req = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ... and then take the reciprocal.

title: AC Circuit Impedance
description: Calculate the impedance of an RLC circuit at a specific frequency.
solution: Impedance Z = sqrt(R² + (X_L - X_C)²), where X_L = 2πfL and X_C = 1/(2πfC).

title: Transformer Turns Ratio
description: Determine the primary and secondary voltages given the transformer turns ratio.
solution: The voltage ratio equals the turns ratio: V_primary/V_secondary = N_primary/N_secondary.

title: Power Factor Correction
description: Calculate the capacitor size required for power factor correction in an AC circuit.
solution: Use the reactive power equation Q = V²/X_C. Adjust the capacitance so that the reactive power compensates for the lagging power factor.

title: RC Circuit Time Constant
description: Determine the time constant of an RC circuit used for capacitor charging.
solution: The time constant τ = RC, which indicates how quickly the capacitor charges.

title: RL Circuit Decay
description: Determine the decay of current in an RL circuit over time.
solution: Current decay follows I(t) = I₀ * exp(-t/τ) with τ = L/R.

title: DC Circuit Power Calculation
description: Calculate the power dissipated by a resistor in a DC circuit.
solution: Power can be calculated using P = I²R or P = V²/R, depending on the given values.

title: Diode Forward Bias
description: Explain the behavior of a diode in a forward bias condition.
solution: When forward biased, a diode begins conducting current after surpassing its threshold voltage (about 0.7V for silicon diodes).

title: MOSFET Saturation Region
description: Describe how a MOSFET operates in the saturation region.
solution: In saturation, the MOSFET functions as a constant current source, where the drain current is relatively insensitive to the drain-source voltage.

title: 2-Input AND Gate Truth Table
description: Construct the truth table for a 2-input AND gate.
solution: The truth table: 0 AND 0 = 0, 0 AND 1 = 0, 1 AND 0 = 0, and 1 AND 1 = 1.

title: Ideal Op-Amp in Negative Feedback
description: Describe the ideal behavior of an operational amplifier configured with negative feedback.
solution: An ideal op-amp in negative feedback will drive its output such that the voltage difference between the inverting and non-inverting inputs is nearly zero.

title: RC Low-Pass Filter Cutoff Frequency
description: Calculate the cutoff frequency of an RC low-pass filter.
solution: The cutoff frequency is given by f_c = 1/(2πRC).

title: Laplace Transform in RLC Circuit
description: Use Laplace transforms to solve a differential equation describing an RLC circuit.
solution: Transform the circuit to the s-domain, solve the resulting algebraic equation, and then apply the inverse Laplace transform to return to the time domain.

title: Fourier Series Representation
description: Determine the Fourier series representation of a given periodic waveform.
solution: Express the waveform as a sum of sine and cosine functions with coefficients computed over one period.

title: Bode Plot Analysis
description: Interpret a Bode plot to assess system stability and gain margin.
solution: Examine the phase and gain margins on the Bode plot; positive margins generally indicate a stable system.

title: Circuit Simulation with SPICE
description: Explain the process of simulating a circuit using SPICE software.
solution: Model the circuit components in SPICE, set up simulation parameters, run the simulation, and analyze the voltage/current responses.

title: Thermal Analysis of an Electronic Component
description: Calculate the temperature rise of an electronic component due to power dissipation.
solution: Use the formula ΔT = P × θ, where P is the power dissipated and θ is the thermal resistance.

title: Electric Field of a Charged Sphere
description: Determine the electric field at a point outside a uniformly charged sphere.
solution: For points outside the sphere, treat it as a point charge: E = kQ/r², where k is Coulomb's constant.
